content:
CompSci 261P - Data Structures - Fall, 2019 (Dillencourt)

  • Homework Assignments: Click here.
  • Lab Assignments: Click here.
  • Course Announcements: Click here.
  • Course Instructor:
    • Professor Michael Dillencourt
    • Email: dillenco at ics dot uci dot edu. But before sending me email please note:
      • Questions of general interest about the course material, the homework, and the tests should be posted to Piazza.
      • Regrade requests on the homework and midterms will be handled through GradeScope.
      • It is much better to use the ics261p-questions list as discussed in the section Sending us email.
    • Office Hours: TBA
      • On Wednesday October 2, the Discussion Section will serve as an office hour. I will stay as long as there are questions.
  • Teaching Assistant:
    • Mr. Pedro Matias
      • Email: pmatias at uci dot edu. But it is much better to use the cs261p-questions list as discussed in the section Sending us email.
      • Office Hours: TBA
  • Reader:
    • Mr. James Liu
      • Email: jamesal1 at uci dot edu But it is much better to use the cs261p-questions list as discussed in the section Sending us email.
      • Office Hours: By appointment
  • Sending us email:
    • Rather than sending email to one of us individually, it is much better to send email to the address: cs261p-questions@uci.edu. This is an alias for the instructor, the TA, and the Reader. Sending your question here ensures that all of us see your message and the response. It may also give you better turnaround time.
  • Class meetings:
    • Lecture: MW 6:30PM-7:50PM, SH 128
    • Discussion/Lab: W 8:00PM-8:50PM, SH 128
    • The first class will be Monday, September 30.
    • There will be no class on the following University holiday:
      • Monday, November 11 (Veteran's Day)
    • Note: The Discussion/Lab sections will be used for
      • Introduction of the lab projects
      • Continuation of the midterms (so you will have 140 minutes rather than 80 minutes for the midterms)
      • Possibly, makeups of missed lectures. (I do not currently have plans to miss any lectures, but just in case ...)
      If none of the above is scheduled, the Discussion/Lab section will be an opportunity to ask questions of the instructor and/or the TA. If nobody has any questions, the Discussion/Lab section may end early that evening.
  • Grading:
    • Midterm Exam 1: 35%
    • Midterm Exam 2: 45%
    • Optional Final Exam: 0%
    • Homework: 5%
    • Projects: 15%
  • Midterm Exam 1:
    • Wednesday, November 6, 6:30PM-8:50PM in the same classroom where lectures are held.
  • Midterm Exam 2:
    • Wednesday, December 4, 6:30PM-8:50PM in the same classroom where lectures are held.
  • Optional Final Exam:
    • Friday, December 13, 7:00PM-9:00PM in the same classroom where lectures are held. This exam is optional. Doing well on it may raise your grade, but doing poorly on it or skipping it entirely will not lower your grade. Details of how this will work will be announced towards the end of the quarter.
  • Course textbook:
    • There is no required textbook. Copies of the lecture notes that I use in class will be available online. (See section on "Course Notes", below.)
    • Much of the course material will be drawn from selected Wikipedia articles and topics in the Wikipedia "book" Fundamental Data Structures.
    • You may also find the open content textbook Open Data Structures useful.
    • In addition, I have requested that the following books be put on reserve in the Science Library:
      • Cormen, Leiserson, Rivest, and Stein, Introduction to Algorithms , 3rd Edition, MIT Press, 2009.
      • Goodrich and Tamassia, Data Structures and algorithms in Java, Wiley, 2006.
      • Goodrich, Tamassia, and Mount, Data Structures and algorithms in C++, Wiley, 2011.
      • Goodrich and Tamassia, Algorithm Design and Applications, Wiley, 2015.
      • Kleinberg and Tardos, Algorithm Design, Pearson/Addison Wesley, 2006.
  • Course Notes (registered students only):
    • Course notes, in the form of slides used for the lectures, are available here. Access is restricted to students enrolled in the course. Authentication information will be given out in class.
  • Tentative schedule of topics. The following schedule is approximate and may change over the course of the quarter.
    • Week 1: Introduction. Abstract data types and data structures. Worst case vs. amortized complexity. Stacks, queues, and deques. The potential method of amortized analysis. Dynamic arrays.
    • Weeks 2-3: The dictionary problem and hash tables. Hash chaining, linear probing, and cuckoo hashing. Hash functions: cryptographic hash functions, k-independent hashing, tabulation hashing.
    • Week 4: Representing sets. Bloom filters. Priority queues. Binary heaps and k-ary heaps. Fibonacci heaps
    • Week 5: Binary search trees and predecessor queries. Balanced binary trees: AVL Trees, Red-Black Trees, WAVL trees.
    • Week 6: Alternatives to balanced binary trees: B-trees, Treaps, Skip lists. Splay trees. Midterm 1.
    • Weeks 7-8: [Veteran's Day Holiday] Tries and suffix trees. Range searching, and augmented binary search trees.
    • Weeks 9-10: Union-find. Review. Possible additional topics. Midterm 2.
Last modified: October 7, 2019
